name: Big Thicket National Preserve
description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats meet in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.
shortDescription: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats meet in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meande...

operatingHours.description: Big Thicket National Preserve is open 24 hours. To camp in the preserve, you need a backcountry camping permit, available from the visitor center.

climate.weatherDescription: SPRING: Expect comfortable weather in Mar/Apr, with heat & humidity increasing in May. SUMMER: High heat, high humidity, and thunderstorms are common. Hurricane & tropical storm activity peaks in late summer. FALL: Early fall can be hot, while Oct/Nov bring pleasant temperatures. WINTER: Mild, chilly weather with occasional cold spells. Snow is rare. Some Dec/Jan/Feb nights may dip below freezing.

images.title: Wintry Cypress Slough
images.altText: Leafless bald cypress trees and knees stand in a swamp filled with leaves and branches in winter.
images.caption: Winter brings a different mood to Big Thicket's sloughs.

images.title: Beaver Slide Trail
images.altText: Tupelo trees growing on the edge of a reflective pond in the woods in spring.
images.caption: A still pond reflects the bright shades of green of early spring.

images.title: Kirby Nature Trail
images.altText: A leaf-covered trail leading through a tree tunnel of dense green vegetation.
images.caption: A thicket is a dense forest of trees and shrubs.

images.title: Staley Cabin
images.altText: A log cabin in a forest beneath a canopy of sprawling live oak trees.
images.caption: Historic Staley Cabin sits at the start of the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.title: Palmettos
images.altText: A patch of palmettos glowing in warm afternoon sunlight in a forest.
images.caption: Dwarf palmettos add a jungle-like atmosphere to the Big Thicket.

images.title: Pitcher Plant
images.altText: Close-up of a carnivorous pitcher plant with the shadow of an insect inside.
images.caption: Visit in spring to see carnivorous pitcher plants.

images.title: Red-Headed Woodpecker
images.altText: A woodpecker with bright red head clinging to a dead tree.
images.caption: Look for woodpeckers in Big Thicket's pine forests.

images.title: Collins Pond, Woodlands Trail
images.altText: A calm pond reflecting red, green, and yellow foliage of trees along its shore.
images.caption: Big Thicket's fall colors typically peak late November through early December.

images.title: Village Creek Bridge
images.altText: An iron bridge above a murky creek surrounded by dense woods.
images.caption: The bridge over Village Creek connects the Kirby Nature Trail to the Turkey Creek Trail.

images.title: Cypress Knees
images.altText: Shadowy-looking cypress knees and their reflections in still water.
images.caption: Cypress knees, extensions of bald cypresses' roots, are abundant in Big Thicket waters.
